title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that diminishing marginal returns begin after the third worker and/or does not explain that the marginal product (MP) of the fourth worker (4) is less than the MP of the third worker (5).
The response states that diminishing marginal returns begin after the third worker and explains that the marginal product (MP) of the fourth worker (4) is less than the MP of the third worker (5).

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not calculate the marginal revenue product of the sixth worker as $18 and/or does not show the work.

The response calculates the marginal revenue product of the sixth worker as $18 and shows the work.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that 5 workers will be hired to maximize its profit and/or does not explain that the marginal revenue product (MRP) of the 5th worker ($27) is greater than the marginal resource cost (MRC) or wage ($25), but the MRP of the 6th worker ($18) is less than the MRC ($25).

The response states that 5 workers will be hired to maximize its profit and explains that the marginal revenue product (MRP) of the 5th worker ($27) is greater than the marginal resource cost (MRC) or wage ($25), but the MRP of the 6th worker ($18) is less than the MRC ($25).

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does none of the following:

· States that the market wage will increase and explains that an increase in the market demand for haircut services will lead to an increase in demand for barbers because the demand for barbers is dependent on (or derived from) the demand for haircut services.

· States that the marginal revenue product curve for the firm will shift to the right and explains that the marginal revenue product is the price of the service times the marginal product, so an increase in the demand for haircut services will increase the market price of haircut services and will therefore increase the marginal revenue product for every unit of labor.

The response does one of the following:

· States that the market wage will increase and explains that an increase in the market demand for haircut services will lead to an increase in demand for barbers because the demand for barbers is dependent on (or derived from) the demand for haircut services.

· States that the marginal revenue product curve for the firm will shift to the right and explains that the marginal revenue product is the price of the service times the marginal product, so an increase in the demand for haircut services will increase the market price of haircut services and will therefore increase the marginal revenue product for every unit of labor.

The response does both of the following:

· States that the market wage will increase and explains that an increase in the market demand for haircut services will lead to an increase in demand for barbers because the demand for barbers is dependent on (or derived from) the demand for haircut services.

· States that the marginal revenue product curve for the firm will shift to the right and explains that the marginal revenue product is the price of the service times the marginal product, so an increase in the demand for haircut services will increase the market price of haircut services and will therefore increase the marginal revenue product for every unit of labor.
